g.text: AS
Client
RS
AS
Client
RS
AS
• acts in the role of a Security Token Service (STS)
• supports the Token Exchange extension of OAuth 2.0
• supports Mutual-TLS Client Certificate-Bound Access Tokens
Client:
• supports Mutual-TLS Client Certificate-Bound Access Tokens,
the Subject Alternative Name (SAN) of the public client certificate is used
as a global client identifier in respect of the email provider it represents,
e.g., SAN = DNS:_smtp-client.foo.127.0.0.1.nip.io
• is registered at the AS as a confidential client
• acts as a client in respect of the RS
RS:
• supports Mutual-TLS Client Certificate-Bound Access Tokens
• uses the information in the assertion to identify the user
and makes authorization decisions using a local ABAC engine
• should support the AS issuer discovery mechanism
1. Client generates a token — a signed certificate-bound assertion
in JWT format with these claims:
{iss, aud, sub, exp, nbf, cnf, act{sub}}
• iss is the URI that identifies who issues the token, e.g. urn:domain:mta:clientid
• aud identifies the target AS
• sub identifies the user by the email address
(Client impersonates the user by using their email address)
• exp, nbf are the standard JWT claims
• cnf is the confirmation method with the hash of the client certificate
to which the token is bound
2. Send an HTTP request to the AS STS endpoint using mTLS
• grant_type = urn:ietf:params:oauth:grant-type:token-exchange
• resource = a target RS URI
• requested_token_type = urn:ietf:params:oauth:token-type:jwt
• subject_token = token
• subject_token_type = urn:ietf:params:oauth:token-type:jwt
3. Authorization decision:
1. evaluate the resource parameter
2. verify the subject_token signature
3. evaluate the subject_token claims
4. AS STS generates a token — a signed certificate-bound assertion
in JWT format with these claims:
{iss, aud, sub, exp, nbf, cnf, act{sub}}
• iss is the URI that identifies who issues the token
• aud identifies the target service and it is the value from
the resource parameter
• sub identifies the user by the email address
retrieved through subject_token introspection
• exp, nbf are the standard JWT claims
• cnf is the confirmation method with the hash of the client certificate
to which the token is bound
• act{sub} is the global client identifier derived from the SAN of the client's
public certificate in the DNS format, e.g., _smtp-client.foo.127.0.0.1.nip.io
(act identifies the acting party to whom authority has been delegated)
5. Return the token
{"access_token":token,
"issued_token_type":"urn:ietf:params:oauth:token-type:jwt",
"token_type":"N_A",
"expires_in":3600}
6. Send an HTTP request to the RS with the token using mTLS
7. Authorization decision
1. verify the token signature
2. validate proof-of-possession
3. use WebFinger to locate the AS for the user using
its identifier and verify that the AS matches the token issuer
or
the domain part of the users's email address
and the AS host domain must match
8. Return the HTTP response, typically with 200, 201 status code
